author: yahoo
title: Líderes evangélicos ucranianos denuncian persecuciones sistemáticas bajo la ocupación rusa
text:
EFE Latam Líderes evangélicos ucranianos denuncian persecuciones sistemáticas bajo la ocupación rusa Agencia EFE 25 de mayo de 2024, 1:26 p. m. · 4 min de lectura Enlace copiado Leer todo el artículo
Kiev, 25 may (EFE).- Líderes de las iglesias evangélicas, bautistas, pentecostales y protestantes de Ucrania denuncian las persecuciones sistemáticas que sus correligionarios sufren en las zonas del país bajo control de Rusia, cuyas autoridades de ocupación perciben a estos cristianos como “agentes occidentales” hostiles a la Iglesia Ortodoxa oficial.
“En la región de Zaporiyia tenemos 21 iglesias bajo ocupación, de las que 14 están siendo utilizadas por los ocupantes; el resto permanecen cerradas y no tienen permisos para funcionar”, dijo a EFE el pastor Yuri Kulakévich, de la Iglesia Pentecostal de Ucrania.
Las confiscaciones de templos que acaban convertidos en barracas del Ejército ruso son habituales en los territorios ocupados de Ucrania, según los testimonios de integrantes de estas comunidades que tomaron fuerza en esta parte de Europa a principios del siglo XX con el retorno como misioneros de inmigrantes ucranianos que se habían hecho evangélicos en Norteamérica.
Secuestros y asesinatos
La toma de iglesias no es el único, ni el peor abuso, sufrido por los pentecostales en la Ucrania bajo control ruso.
En marzo de 2022, poco después de la caída en manos rusas de Jersón, el hijo del obispo pentecostal de esta provincia del sur de Ucrania Oleksandr Babiychuk fue secuestrado mientras repartía suministros en pueblos afectados por la guerra.
“Pese a que se dirigió repetidamente al KGB y las demás autoridades rusas en la zona”, afirmó el pastor Kulakvéich utilizando las siglas del antecesor soviético del actual servicio secreto ruso, “la familia no supo nada de él durante ocho meses”.
El motivo del secuestro de Zhenia Babiychuk le fue revelado a su padre con una llamada en la que le invitaron a cooperar y promover una imagen positiva de las autoridades de ocupación rusas si quería volver a ver a su hijo.
“Se nos acusaba de ser espías estadounidenses disfrazados de organización religiosa”, declaró Babiychuk sénior para un informe del Instituto para la Libertad Religiosa de Ucrania.
Conciencia y autonomía
Además de en la hostilidad a lo diferente, la animadversión de las autoridades de ocupación rusas hacia las distintas familias de evangelistas se fundamenta, según Kulakévich, en los orígenes anglosajones de estas denominaciones y en su naturaleza descentralizada y difícil, por tanto, de someter y controlar.
“Ven las iglesias evangélicas como un poder oculto que puede influir en la sociedad porque saben que sus integrantes son gente flexible que hace lo que cree correcto sin buscar aprobación o temer las consecuencias”, explica el pastor. “Cada comunidad está autogobernada y esta independencia es percibida como una amenaza”, agrega.
Las acusaciones de ser espías occidentales y el recelo que provoca el dinamismo evangélico entre las autoridades impuestas por Rusia en Ucrania retrotraen a esta minoría cristiana a los tiempos de la Unión Soviética.
Hijo, nieto y sobrino de líderes pastores evangélicos deportados y condenados a trabajos forzosos bajo el régimen comunista que imponía Moscú, Kulakévich sufrió en el colegio actos de repudio y humillación pública promovidos por sus propios profesores debido a su condición de evangélico.
“Sabemos lo que es vivir bajo el Imperio que quiere restaurar (el presidente ruso, Vladímir) Putin y no queremos eso para nuestros hijos”, señaló el pastor pentecostal.
El del hijo del obispo de esta denominación en Jersón no es el único secuestro de líderes evangélicos a manos de las autoridades rusas y sus lugartenientes en Ucrania.
Represalias y torturas
En septiembre de 2021, el pastor bautista de Mariúpol Leonid Ponomariov fue secuestrado y detenido durante un mes por soldados rusos por no prestar su iglesia para que se celebrará el referéndum convocado allí por Moscú para justificar la anexión del territorio a la Federación Rusa.
Menos suerte tuvieron el pastor evangélico Oleksandr Prokopchuk y su hijo Anatoli, torturados hasta la muerte en la región ocupada de Jersón días después de su secuestro en noviembre de 2022.
Pese a la persecución que sufren sus correligionarios en los territorios controlados por Rusia en Ucrania, una parte de los círculos evangélicos del Partido Republicano de EEUU ve a Putin como un adalid del conservadurismo y la religión y se ha opuesto de forma sistemática al envío de ayuda a Kiev.
Una delegación de líderes evangélicos ucranianos viajó el pasado mes de febrero a EEUU para convencer a los legisladores cristianos del Congreso de que Putin no es un aliado de su causa, sino el peor enemigo de la libertad religiosa que constituye uno de los pilares fundacionales de Estados Unidos.
por Marcel Gascón
(c) Agencia EFE

author: Staff Report
title: Local roundup: Tewksbury's Sammy Taber nets college hockey national honor
text: Making the jump from prep school hockey to Division 1 college hockey has humbled many a player. But not Tewksbury native Sammy Taber, who’s piling up the points – and honors – during her freshman season on the Boston College women’s team. The 5-foot-5 forward leads the Eagles with 17 assists and 23 points. She was recently selected the Rookie of the Month by the Hockey Commissioners Association for her exploits in December. Taber, a member of the bronze medal-winning 2023 U.S. Under-18 Women’s National Team at the IIHF U-18 Women’s World Championships in Sweden, scored two goals and eight points in just three games for the 14th-ranked Eagles. Those eight points tied for the NCAA rookie lead in scoring in December and her plus-8 rating was the best out of any freshman in the country. Taber starred at Cushing Academy before enrolling at BC. Wrestling Lions second: Host Chelmsford captured second place at the Bruce Rich Invitational. The Lions (190) topped the field except for MVC rival Central Catholic (211.5), which had lost a dual meet to Chelmsford earlier in the week. Thomas Brown won the 285-pound title for CHS. Captain Jose Bethel was the runner-up at 190. Finishing fourth were Teddy Sheridan at 132 and Michael Korch at 144. Austin Hill took fifth at 138. Lowell goes 3-1: The Red Raiders impressed during a home quad meet in a performance highlighted by a 36-34 win over MVC rival Andover. Heavyweight Jaevion Rosado Cunningham secured the win over Andover with a pin for the Red Raiders (8-2, 4-0 MVC). Greater Lowell perfect: The Gryphons (11-2) went 4-0 with victories over Salem (40-39), Marlboro (42-33), Martha’s Vineyard (66-6) and Wilmington (45-21). Going 4-0 were Antoine Jackman at 106, Garrett Ayotte at 144 and Jorge Lora at 165. Picking up three wins were Navi Vongphoumy at 132 and Gabe Stickney 150/157. Clark takes fourth: Westford Academy senior Shane Clark earned fourth place at 190 at the Bruce Rich Invitational at Chelmsford High. Senior Leo Babineau grabbed fifth at 132 for the Ghosts. Taunton 51, Billerica 30: The Indians dropped the non-league dual meet despite several strong performances. Winning matches for Billerica were Shane Breen at 113 (pin), Peter Rincan at 120 (pin), David Hawkes at 132 (pin), Jackson Gearin at 138 (pin) and Jizaiah Candelario at 165 (pin). Girls hockey M/T 1, Billerica/Chelmsford 0: In a tense thriller, Sammy Ryan of Methuen/Tewksbury scored the game’s lone goal 14 seconds into the third period following a pass by Kat Schille. A goal by Billerica/Chelmsford off the stick of Ruby Boucher which would have tied the game was disallowed with 36 seconds left. Boys hockey Cambridge 6, Lowell 2: Senior Teddy Steinberg and sophomore Shane Peters each tallied a goal and an assist as visiting Lowell fell to Cambridge in a MVC/DCL conference game. Junior Nate Dodge added an assist for the Red Raiders. Weston 2, Littleton 1: Despite a 24-save performance from Charles Becker, Littleton was edged. Conor Glew tallied Littleton’s goal following passes from Liam Glew and Zachary Lizotte. Bedford 2, Dracut/Tyngsboro 0: Dracut/Tyngsboro couldn’t solve Bedford’s defense. Wilmington 0, Stoneham 0: The Middlesex League teams skated to a rare overtime tie with featured strong goaltending by both squads. For Wilmington, Tyler Marinho stopped 28 shots to collect his first varsity shutout. Central Catholic 6, Billerica 1: A balanced scoring attack led Central past Billerica. Scoring goals for the Raiders were Jake Morowski, Aiden Pinet, Brady Rickenbach, Adam Godfrey, Keegan Hunt and Ryan Melesky. Logan Sheedy made 16 saves for Central (2-5-1). Concord-Carlisle 5, Tewksbury 2: In a battle of area powers, Concord-Carlisle remained undefeated (8-0) with a win at Edge Sports in Bedford. Tewksbury (5-1) held a 33-18 shots advantage. Jeremy Insogna netted a goal and assist. Michael Connors also scored for the Redmen. Dishing out an assist each were Matthew Cooke and Tyler Bourgea. Owen Sovie made 13 saves between the pipes. NM 5, Groton-Dunstable 4: Brady Lavery scored 1:20 into overtime to lift North Middlesex to the thrilling victory at the Groton School. Sean Myers scored twice for NM (5-2), Max Caliri had a goal and assist, and Brady Dunbar set up the winning goal. For Groton-Dunstable (1-5), Mac Kahwati netted a hat trick and Griffin Southwick added the other tally. Girls track LHS excels: Lowell High soared in the Reggie Lewis Center at the MSTCA Freshman-Sophomore Championship, earning three individual medals. Freshman Kayla Moriarty posted a personal best of 28-4.5 on her last throw in the shot put to place fourth. Sophomore Ella Machado also finished fourth with a time of 5:31.00 in the mile. Rounding out the medalists for Lowell was sophomore Chasity Jennings, who placed sixth in the long jump with a leap of 15-5.75. McEleney wins: Groton-Dunstable’s Meghan McEleney won the girls 600-meter race in 1:41.22 at the MSTCA Freshman/Sophomore meet with a big personal best. CHS duo shines: Chelmsford teammates Kate Leonard and Mia McCusker finished second and eighth, respectively, in the MSTCA Freshman-Sophomore Championship. Leonard crossed in 5:24, while McCusker finished in 5:41. Boys swimming Westford 92, Concord-Carlisle 88: The Ghosts pulled out a thrilling Dual County League victory. Aiden Gouldson won the 200 free (1:51.10) and 100 backstroke (1:03.01), and was part of the winning medley relay (1:41.10) and 400 free relay (3:22.68) teams. Han Park captured the 200 IM for the Ghosts in 2:02.85, and Owen Curtin won the 50 free in 23.83. Park was also on the winning 400 free relay team. Girls swimming Concord-Carlisle 97, Westford 80: The Ghosts dropped the Dual County League meet despite victories from three swimmers. Capturing wins were Estella Cui in the 100 butterfly in 1:03.16, Catherine Newark in the 100 free in 57.07 and Sherry Ye in the 100 backstroke.

author: Ana Luiza Nogueira
title: SAD/SEJUSP/PCMS do Mato Grosso do Sul promovem 400 vagas em novo Concurso Público
text:
A Secretaria de Estado de Administração, a Secretaria de Estado de Justiça e Segurança Pública e a Polícia Civil de Mato Grosso do Sul (SAD/SEJUSP/PCMS) anunciaram a abertura de inscrições para um novo Concurso Público com o objetivo de preencher 400 vagas para Agente de Polícia Judiciária.
Segundo o edital, as oportunidades são para as funções de: Investigador de Polícia Judiciária (300 vagas); Escrivão de Polícia Judiciária (100 vagas).
Podem concorrer candidatos com diploma de ensino superior completo, em nível de graduação, em qualquer área, reconhecido pelo Ministério da Educação, e CNH, no mínimo categoria B.
A carga horária prevista é de 40 horas semanais, com remuneração mensal no valor de R$ 6.569,53.
Os interessados podem se inscrever no site da Avalia, no período de 16 de julho de 2025 até as 23h59 do dia 7 de agosto de 2025. O valor da taxa de inscrição é de R$ 210,48.
O período para solicitar a isenção da taxa de inscrição é de 16 de julho de 2025 até as 15h do dia 21 de julho de 2025.
A seleção acontecerá por meio das seguintes etapas: prova escrita objetiva, prevista para o dia 14 de setembro de 2025, prova de títulos, avaliação psicológica, avaliação médico-odontológica e avaliação de aptidão física. A segunda etapa do concurso será constituída pelo curso de formação policial de caráter eliminatório.
O prazo de validade do Concurso Público será de dois anos, contados a partir da data da publicação, no Diário Oficial Eletrônico, da homologação do Concurso Público pelo Governador do Estado, após a divulgação do resultado final da primeira turma de candidatos que realizaram o Curso de Formação Policial, podendo ser prorrogado, uma única vez, por igual período.
Está buscando sucesso neste concurso? Nossas Apostilas Digitais podem ser seu grande aliado!

author: @ODNMalaysia
title: 环境部：5年24宗地陷　重新检讨敏感区开发标准
text:
（吉隆坡6日讯）根据马来西亚矿物及地质科学局（JMG）记录，我国在过去5年通报24宗地陷事件，霹雳占11宗高居榜首。
天然资源及环境永续部在国会网站发布的书面答复中说，吉隆坡和槟州分别录得3宗地陷事件、吉兰丹2宗；森美兰、吉打、雪兰莪、马六甲和玻璃市各1宗。
“本部门通过矿物及地质科学局向来致力在涉及地陷地质灾害敏感地区的开发区，降低发生地质灾害的风险。”
环境部在回答伊斯兰党勿述国会议员拿督仄莫哈末祖基菲里要求该部说明，国内在过去5年通报的地陷事件总数，以及该部门在应对此课题所采取的举措。
环境部说，矿物及地质科学局对地质危险和风险评估提供意见，并参与制定各级的国家发展规划标准。
该部也同意重新检讨涉及地质灾害敏感区，尤其是地陷区的开发标准。
“所需著重的主要信息是开发地段的环境地质信息，成为准备开发建议报告和岩土报告的基础。”
要看最快最熱資訊，請來Follow我們 《東方日報》WhatsApp Channel.

Show Me No thanks, close See our Privacy Notice If you visit Weston-Super-Mare in the coming weeks you may bump into a real life Superman. Tom Young is running 46 half marathons in 46 weeks to mark the 46 days he spent with his son Jaxon, all while dressed as the comic book hero.
Jaxon passed away in his parents' arms at St Michael's Hospital in Bristol last May. Tom hopes to raise £5,000 for Cots for Tots, a fundraising appeal for the neonatal intensive care unit at the hospital.
Neither knee injuries nor torrential rain can slow Thomas down. When asked how he trained, he replied: "In all honesty, pure stubbornness. If I set my sight on a goal, I tend to do it."
READ MORE: Weston-Super-Mare Mayor completes charity run in "hammering" rain
READ MORE: Somerset man becomes the Tower of London's newest 'Beefeater'
Thomas has persisted in his goal despite a painful sports injury. He said: "In the early stages of doing this, I was doing football and I twisted my knee. I'm not entirely sure what's up with it, it's either a strained ligament or a slight tear.
"When I did that, I had a run the next day. Even running with a bad leg, I managed to beat my time the previous week."
Tom has been running with a painful injury at times He also completes the half marathons come rain or shine. "Last week's it started off really light rain and I thought I could get away with it, but by the time I got to the twelfth mile the heavens just opened", he recalled.
"Because of the rain, my superman suit was basically a weighted suit towards the end of it. So the last mile or so I ended up walking it because I couldn't run anymore."
The community have rallied behind Tom, who shot past his original goal of raising £1,000 long before the finish line. He said: "When I first started I was getting a few beeps, but I don't think people realised what I was doing at first.
"I think they just thought I was running round Weston in a superman suit for a laugh."
He has had huge support from the community However, his runs are now a well-known fixture in the town: "I hope that it gives people a boost. Some of the people who comment on my page say that their sons and daughters have said that they've seen superman today and they loved it."
Thomas plans to finish his last run on the anniversary of his son's passing, at St Michael's Hospital on Tuesday, 14 May. He said: "When I first started I was really energetic, but now I'm getting closer and closer to the finish line, I think my body's telling me that it's getting a little bit tired now."
Cots for Tots raises money for the neonatal intensive care unit at St Michael's. They fund life-saving equipment, offer nearby accommodation for families, and even provide music therapy for the children.
You can support Tom's fundraiser online.
